items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: High river levels are expected to cause flooding on 4th February 2026. Further rainfall is forecast and river levels remain high. During periods of high tide, the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Refer to Local Authority website for road closures. This message will be updated by 01:00PM on 5th February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: High river levels today, 4th February 2026 may lead to flooding. This information is correct as of 3:45pm on 4th February 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 11cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 9cm of water on the road. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Thursday 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Combe Haven
items.message: The Combe Haven at Bulverhythe is high, following recent wet weather. Minor flood impacts are expected to continue affecting Bexhill Road Recreation Ground. Moderate rain is forecast for much of Thursday. The Powdermill Stream in Crowhurst, and the Combe Haven in Bulverhythe are expected to rise a little. From 10:00 on 05/02/2026, minor flooding could affect fields and roads in Crowhurst. In Bulverhythe, river levels will remain higher than normal all week. There is uncertainty, but property flooding could be possible from Thursday evening. We are closely monitoring the situation. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have in Crowhurst. This message will be updated by 20:00 on 05/02/2026.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level remains high and the drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.48m and stable. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road if this drain level exceeds 7.30m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Draycott road above 8.80m. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once river spillways stop running. Wednesday will be a mainly dry day but further rainfall, heavy at times is forecast through Thursday and Friday.   We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1PM on 05/02/2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Blackwater
items.message:
High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 as a lot of rain is forecast (25mm). 
Flooding could affect land, fields, and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels may also be very high around, and affect the mill building at East Wellow. Lighter rain (up to 10mm) is forecast on Friday (06/02/2026). River levels will remain higher than normal, and flood risk will continue into the weekend. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have , including pumps. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels in Alfriston remain higher than normal following Tuesday's rain. A small amount of rain is forecast Thursday morning. River levels will rise again. From 06:00 on 05/02/2026 minor flooding could affect fields and roads, including at Hammer Lane, Grove Hill, and gardens on Mill Lane, Hellingly. From 09:00 on 05/02/2026 minor flooding could affect fields, and gardens on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 15:00 on 05/02/2026 minor flooding could affect fields and North Street, Alfriston. More rain is forecast Thursday evening and Friday. River levels could rise higher, and property flooding could be possible Friday. We are closely monitoring the situation. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly, and North Street Alfriston. This message will be updated by 18:00 on 05/02/2026.

Similar to recent days. From 12:00 05/02/2026, minor flooding could affect fields between Liss and Midhurst. From 18:00 05/02/2026, minor flood impacts could again occur at Lodsbridge near Selham and continue in Fittleworth. More rain is forecast Thursday evening and through Friday. items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message:
High tides on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 2 hours either side of Thursday's early morning tide at 01:30 on 05/02/2026. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.31 m. Total forecast tide is 6.15 metres Chart Datum (3.10 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Strong Easterly Force 6 wind. Small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Thursday's tide at 13:45 05/02/2026 is forecast to be 6 cm lower (3.04 mAOD). Flood impacts are predicted each high tide until Friday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation We routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have Access could be restricted. Take care if visiting Climping beach. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding over the evening tide on Wednesday 4 February and morning tide on Thursday 5 February.

Areas particularly at risk include exposed coastal areas of Plymouth Sound including Cawsand, Kingsand and The Hoe, Millbrook and low lying areas on the Tidal Lynher, Tamar, Tavy, Plym and Yealm estuaries.

The high tide at Plymouth on Wednesday evening is 19:48 and Thursday morning is at 08:00, times of high water will vary along the coast.  

Forecast total high tide level is 2.76m and 3.02mAOD repectivley. Expect tide levels along the coast to be between 0.5 and 0.7 metres above tide table level. Force 7 easterly winds tonight moving to force 4 Southerly winds on Thursday and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast over the high tide. 

Coastal conditions should ease for Thursday evening's high tide.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message: The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.61m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.62m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and additional pumps are operational at Northmoor.  Wednesday will be a mainly dry day but further rainfall, heavy at times is forecast through Thursday and Friday. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1PM on 05/02/2026 or as the situation changes

items.description: Mansbridge and Riverside Park
items.message: High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 05/02/2026, because of the combination of river flows and high tides. The next high tides are forecast 00:45 and 03:15 on Thursday morning (05/02/2026). The water level is expected to be 4.96 metres Chart Datum (2.22 mAOD). Flooding will affect the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Water may be forced up through the floor of the Pub. Riverside Park will also be flooded. Levels may also be very high around Gaters Mill. Thursday's tide at 13:00 on 05/02/2026 is forecast to be 2cm higher. Flooding impacts will be similar. More rain is forecast on Thursday so flows in the River Itchen will remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are liaising with Southampton City Council on operation of Woodmill. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have, including defences around the White Swan pub. This message will be updated by 19:00 on 05/02/2026.

items.description: Monks Brook
items.message:
High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 as a lot of rain is forecast (25mm). 
If as much rain falls as forecast, flooding could affect the recreation ground at Fleming Park, and the river will be very high at Kingfisher Road. Surface water flooding could affect roads in Chandlers Ford, and at Stoneham Way from Chestnut Way to the M27. A similar event to yesterday, 03/02/2025. Today is forecast to be dry. If as much rain falls as forecast tomorrow, levels will start to rise tomorrow morning. River levels and flood risk will remain high for the next few days. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions Report blockages to our hotline 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lymington River
items.message:
High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 as a lot of rain is forecast (25mm). 
Flooding could affect land and roads, including Burley Road, Brockenhurst. The river will be bank full as it flows through Martin’s Road and Balmer Lawn Road and may cause garden flooding at Balmer Lawn Road. In Lymington itself, the river will rise throughout Thursday (05/02/2026). Lighter rain (up to 10mm) is forecast on Friday 06/02/2026. River levels will remain higher than normal, and flood risk may continue into the weekend depending on how much rain is recorded on Thursday (05/02/2026). 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have and avoid driving through watersplash areas in Brockenhurst. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Curry Moor and Hay Moor
items.message: The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.61m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.62m. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 remains closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Wednesday will be a mainly dry day but further rainfall, heavy at times is forecast through Thursday and Friday.  We are monitoring the situation closely and checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1PM on 05/02/2026 or as the situation changes.

Flooding is possible on 04 February 2026 . 
Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible, especially in the Sunbury area. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message:
High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 . 5-10mm of rain is forecast Thursday morning. 
During Wednesday, minor flooding will continue to affect fields, the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road, land at Riverside Caravan Centre. River levels will rise Thursday, but not significantly higher than recent days. From 05:00 05/02/2026, minor flooding could affect Barnham Road and Lake Lane, Barnham. More rain is forecast Thursday evening and through Friday. From Friday evening, it could be possible for a small amount of water to affect Durban Road. Flood risk will continue to at least Monday. River levels in Bersted will remain higher than normal for a fortnight. 
We are closely monitoring the situation clearing debris screens through Barnham. Our pumps at Felpham are running. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have Including in Barnham. Avoid roads that flood (Barnham Rd and Lake Lane). 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lox
items.message:
High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 as 5-10mm  of rain is forecast early Thursday morning. 
During Wednesday, minor flooding will continue to affect fields, roads, gardens along the River Lox and including gardens of isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold and Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. Also near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. River levels will rise again on Thursday, but not significantly higher than recent days. More rain is forecast Thursday evening and through Friday, which could cause river levels to rise more. River levels and flood risk are likely to remain high over the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have Continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Datchet to Shepperton Green
items.message:
River levels remain high.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today 04/02/2026 and tomorrow 05/02/2026, especially in the Penton Hook area. Further rainfall is forecast overnight with tomorrow expected to be a wet day. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 20:00 5 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Langney Haven
items.message: The Langney Haven is high following weeks of rain. Moderate rain is forecast for much of Thursday. The Langney Haven is expected to rise a little. Minor flooding could affect gardens of properties of Langney Green. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park will also be affected. Rain is forecast to stop by Thursday afternoon. More rain is forecast for Thursday evening / Friday. River levels are expected to rise again following this. We are closely monitoring the situation and operating structures at Fence Bridge and Crumbles to reduce flood risk. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Install flood protection products in Langney Green. This message will be updated by 20:00 on 05 February 2026.

items.description: River Adur West Branch
items.message:
High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 04 February 2026 . 
5-10mm of rain is forecast Thursday morning. River levels will rise. Probably to a similar height seen in recent days. From 11:00 05/02/2026, minor flooding will affect fields, rural roads, and possibly gardens between Coolham and Henfield. More rain is forecast Thursday evening and Friday. Further river rise is expected. If as much rain falls as predicted, it could be possible for isolated property flooding Friday. Small amounts of rain are forecast in the outlook, further river rises are possible over the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Don't put yourself or others at risk Avoid roads that flood, including Slaughter Bridge, Coolham Road. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon and tributaries
items.message: This is a flood alert update. River levels are steady but remaining high due to continued rainfall and high groundwater levels. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood. Further rain is expected today and over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Check local authority websites for road closures. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 5 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Carisbrooke and Hunny Hill on the Lukely Brook
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. Tomorrow (05/02/2026) up to 15mm of rainfall is forecast. If realised the river will rise again. A Flood Alert remains in force. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: River Medina
items.message:
High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 as further rain is forecast (15mm). 
If as much rain falls as forecast, flooding could affect land, gardens, and possibly roads at Blackwater, especially at Blackwater Hollow on the A3020 near the Mill Farm and at Sandy Lane. The river could become very high at St George's Way, Shide. A similar event to yesterday 03/02/2026. Today is forecast to be dry. If as much rain falls as forecast tomorrow, levels will start to rise tomorrow morning. River levels will remain high for the next few days. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Avoid flooded ground, flood water could be deep. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message:
High river levels tomorrow may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 as further rainfall (25mm) is forecast tomorrow. 
Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads, cycle tracks and footpaths close to the river. At Langbridge and Alverstone, the river will be close to bank full. Flooding of Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road will continue to occur. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. River levels will remain higher than normal, and flood risk will continue into the weekend. 
We are checking rivers for blockages and operating Bembridge sluices. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have including in Alverstone. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Thames Ditton Island

floodArea.county: Greater London, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
High tides combined with high river flows from upstream may lead to flooding. 

The next high tide is expected at Thames Ditton at 05:00 on 04/02/2026 and is forecast to reach between 5.60m - 5.74m. The following high tide is expected at 17:45 on 05/02/2026 and is forecast to reach between 5.64m - 5.78m. This evening and overnight is forecast to be dry with further rainfall forecast tomorrow, which may be heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days, although we expect tidal peaks to reduce after today.

We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 10:00 05/02/2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Iwerne
items.message: Rising groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. Flooding is expected from 2  February 2026 onwards. Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Iwerne Minster. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, please take care when driving. We are closely monitoring the situation . If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. Please do not drive through floodwater as this may cause bow waves. This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 9 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Fittleworth on the Western River Rother
items.message: The Western Rother is high in Fittleworth. Minor flooding will continue to affect gardens, roads, and fields, and be close to Fittleworth Mill. No rain is forecast Wednesday, river levels will be stable, or may fall a little. More rain is forecast from the early hours of Thursday. River levels could rise a little in Fittleworth Thursday afternoon, but probably not a lot. Further rain is forecast Thursday evening and through Friday, which will cause river levels to rise higher. Potentially affecting properties Saturday. River levels will remain high until next week. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have in Fittleworth. This message will be updated by 20:00 05/02/2026.

items.description: Pulborough on the River Arun
items.message: The River Arun is high following weeks of rain. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect the A29, gardens of properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. No rain is forecast Wednesday. River levels will fall a little. A small amount of rain (5-10mm) is forecast Thursday morning, but we expect river levels to continue to slowly fall Thursday. More rain is forecast Thursday evening and Friday. River levels in Pulborough could rise again Friday. If as much rain falls as predicted, property flooding could be possible in Pulborough Saturday. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce flood risk. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have in Pulborough. This message will be updated by 20:00 05/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels in the Salisbury Plain have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. Levels are forecast to continue to rise throughout the week. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 9 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the South Wiltshire Downs - The Dene

The groundwater level at the Terraces borehole has risen to 118.61m, and is expected to continue to rise throughout this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 10:45AM on 9 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hayling Island
items.message: High tides on Thursday may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible for 2 hours either side of Thursday's early morning tide at 01:15 on 05/02/2026. The weather increases tide table values by 0.31 m. Total forecast tide is 5.05 metres Chart Datum (2.32 mAOD) at Portsmouth with a strong Easterly Force 5 wind. The shingle beach at Eastoke Corner has been impacted by high energy waves. Water could push further up the beach than normal. Property at Eastoke Corner, near the nature reserve, and at Southwood Road may flood. Overtopping of splash walls along the beach front may flood gardens. Beach huts at West Beach, near the Inn on The Beach may also be affected. Thursday’s tide at 13:15 05/02/2026 is forecast to be 0.04m higher (2.36 mAOD).   We are closely monitoring the situation. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Avoid South Hayling seafront. Shingle can be thrown by wind and waves. This message will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday 05/02/2026.

items.description: Mansbridge and Woodmill on the River Itchen
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Thursday. 
Flooding is expected on 05 February 2026 because of the combination of river flows and high tides.   
The next high tide is forecast 00:45 and 03:15 on Thursday morning (05/02/2026). The water level is expected to be 4.96 metres Chart Datum (2.22 mAOD). Flooding will affect the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Water may be forced up through the floor of the Pub. Riverside Park will also be flooded. Levels may also be very high around Gaters Mill. Thursday's tide at 13:00 on 05/02/2026 is forecast to be 2cm higher. Flooding impacts will be similar. More rain is forecast on Thursday (05/02/2026) so flows in the River Itchen will remain high. 
We are checking rivers for blockages and liaising with Southampton City Council on operation of Woodmill. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have including defences around the White Swan pub. 
This message will be updated by 7:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Kingston Deverill, Monkton Deverill, Hill Deverill, Longbridge Deverill, Crockerton, Norton Bavant, Heytesbury, Corton, Upton Lovell, Boyton, Sherrington, Stockton and Bapton. The groundwater level at the Tilshead MOD borehole is 108.06m, and is expected to remain high over the next few days.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.

Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater.

Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 11 February 2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Pitton, West Tytherley, Nether Wallop and Broughton
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 05/02/2026 because of a very wet January 2026. 
Flooding could affect cellars of 1 to 2 properties in Nether Wallop. In Over Wallop, some ponding of water may affect gardens. In Broughton, rising river and groundwater may cause land flooding, which could begin to affect property. Further rain (up to 20mm) is forecast on Thursday (05/02/2026). From Friday (06/02/2026) to Sunday (08/02/2026), lighter rain is forecast. If heavy rain affects the area, then groundwater levels could continue rising into next week. If this happens, then the Dun Tributary could begin flowing towards Pitton from next week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 11 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels remain high and are continuing to rise very slowly at our Draycot borehole in the Upper Og Valley. We expect levels to continue to rise slowly over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

Depending on the rainfall received, we may see localised groundwater impacts. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are closely monitoring rainfall and groundwater levels.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Take particular care when driving through flood water both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. 

This message will be updated by 12:00 11 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Plymouth Sound, Wembury Bay and tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding over the morning tide on Thursday 5 February.

Areas particularly at risk include exposed coastal areas of Plymouth Sound including Cawsand, Kingsand and The Hoe, Millbrook and low lying areas on the Tidal Lynher, Tamar, Tavy, Plym and Yealm estuaries.

The high tide at Plymouth on Thursday morning is at 08:00, times of high water will vary along the coast.  

Forecast total high tide level is 3.02mAOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to be between 0.5 and 0.7 metres above tide table level. Force 4 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast over the high tide. 

Coastal conditions should ease for Thursday evening's high tide.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Hayling and South Eastoke seafront
items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding on Thursday. 
Flooding is expected for 2 hours either side of Thursday's early morning tide at 01:15 on 05/02/2026.   
The weather increases tide table values by 0.31 m. Total forecast tide is 5.05 metres Chart Datum (2.32 mAOD) at Portsmouth with a strong Easterly Force 5 wind. The shingle beach at Eastoke Corner has been impacted by high energy waves. Water could push further up the beach than normal. Property at Eastoke Corner, near the nature reserve, and at Southwood Road may flood. Overtopping of splash walls along the beach front may flood gardens. Beach huts at West Beach, near the Inn on the beach, may also be affected. Thursday's tide at 13:15 on 05/02/2026 is forecast to be 4 cm higher (2.36 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . Avoid South Hayling seafront. Shingle can be thrown by wind and waves. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: Considerable floodwater remains on the Somerset Levels and Moors and upstream river levels remain high. Areas most at risk include locations near the River Yeo, River Parrett and River Cary, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of runway.  Wednesday will be a mainly dry day but further rainfall, heavy at times is forecast through Thursday and Friday. We are closely monitoring the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk. This message will be updated by 1PM on 05/02/2026, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This is a Groundwater Flood Warning Update. Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Pimperne Brook at Pimperne. The groundwater level at Iwerne Hill Farm borehole is 115.23m, and is expected to remain high over the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. Residents should continue to keep any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers deployed. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Keep up to date with groundwater levels on the 'Check for Flooding' site on gov.uk. Please take care and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. items.description: A361 East Lyng to Burrowbridge
items.message: The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.61m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.62m. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 remains closed. For road closure information please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. The River Tone level is still too high for pumping at Currymoor. We will commence pumping here once river levels allow. Wednesday will be a mainly dry day but further rainfall, heavy at times is forecast through Thursday and Friday. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking floodbanks and spillways. Please do not walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 05 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 . 5-10mm of rain is forecast Thursday morning. 
River levels will rise Thursday, but not significantly different or higher than recent days. From 06:00 05/02/2026, minor flooding could affect fields, Brook Meadows, rural roads, and gardens on North Street, River Street and at the Wren Centre, Westbourne. Also near Lumley Mill and Victoria Terrace, Emsworth. More rain is forecast Thursday evening and through Friday. From Friday, it could be possible for a water to be close to properties. We are closely monitoring the situation operating our structure at Constant Springs, and clearing debris screens. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have Including in Westbourne and Emsworth, flooding may occur quickly. 
This message will be updated by 7:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Bere Stream
items.message:
Flooding is expected from 03 February 2026. Groundwater levels in West Dorset are beginning to fall but remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Milton Abbas and Milborne St. Andrew. The groundwater level at the Delcombe Wood borehole has risen to 143.67m. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. We are closely monitoring the situation. If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. 
 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 10 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message: The River Yeo level remains high and the drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.48m and stable. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once spillways stop running. Wednesday will be a mainly dry day but further rainfall, heavy at times, is forecast through Thursday and Friday. We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1PM on 05/02/2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Salt Moor and North Moor including Moorland
items.message: Water levels remain high and continued flooding is expected today, Wednesday 4th February. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads around Moorland including Horlake, Saltmoor, Fordgate and Chadmead. The level in Currymoor is stable, though still very high. Athelney spillway is still running into Saltmoor and Northmoor. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. The River Tone level is still too high for pumping at Currymoor. Wednesday will be a mainly dry day but further rainfall, heavy at times is forecast through Thursday and Friday. Act on your flood plan if you have one. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 1PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Denton
items.message: Groundwater is high, but currently falling at the Houndean Bottom borehole. Light rain is forecast for much of Sunday. Even at such short lead times there is uncertainty in amounts. 20mm of rain could be recorded Sunday. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday. Groundwater is expected to remain high. Springs will appear, water will affect fields, the recreation ground, and a small number of cellars in Denton. If we get the maximum rain Sunday and Tuesday, then groundwater could rise again, and a small amount of water may appear on Denton Road. Very little rain is forecast mid week. Groundwater rise at Houndean Bottom borehole should pause around 06/02/2026. However, with the weather outlook remaining unsettled, and more rain predicted on Friday, further groundwater rise is possible next weekend. Which may cause water to flow towards Vicarage Close and affect areas near the three ponds in South Heighton. Flood impacts may remain until mid February. Take care on roads that flood (Denton Road). Ensure pumps work. We will monitor, and update this message by 18:00 06/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Groundwater is high and slowly rising. Light rain is forecast for much of Sunday. Even at such short lead times there is uncertainty in amounts. 20mm of rain could be recorded Sunday. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday. Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Springs will appear, water will be in fields, and small amounts of water could flow down roads. If we get the maximum rain Sunday and Tuesday, then groundwater could rise higher and faster. Potentially affecting a small number of cellars in Stoughton and Walderton from 04/02/2026. With more water flowing along Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden, between Cooks Lane and Barley Mow in Walderton, the B2146 near Woodlands Lane. Very little rain is forecast mid week. Groundwater rise at Compton borehole should pause around 07/02/2026. However, with the weather outlook remaining unsettled, and more rain predicted on Friday, further groundwater rise is possible next weekend. Take care on roads that flood (Stoughton, Walderton). Ensure pumps work. We will monitor, and update this message by 18:00 06/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Groundwater is high and slowly rising. Light rain is forecast for much of Sunday. Even at such short lead times there is uncertainty in amounts. 20mm of rain could be recorded Sunday. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday. Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Springs will appear, water will be in fields, small amounts of water will flow down roads, groundwater will affect the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean, and may start to appear in a small number of basements. If we get the maximum rain Sunday and Tuesday, then groundwater could rise higher and faster, causing more water to flow on roads. Groundwater rise at Chilgrove borehole should pause around 07/02/2026, but will continue at East Dean borehole until at least the middle of February. With the weather outlook remaining unsettled, and more rain predicted on Friday, further groundwater rise is possible next weekend. Take care on roads that flood (Chilgrove, West Dean, Singleton, East Dean). Ensure pumps work. We will update this message by 18:00 06/02/2026.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water .  This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon at The Friary and City Centre, Salisbury
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. Further rainfall is expected Thursday and Friday, which may cause river levels to rise again. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: The Wallops
items.message:
High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 as a lot of rain is forecast (25mm). 
Flooding may affect low lying land and Horsebridge Road, Broughton, and will be close to property at Duck’s Lane, Church Street and The Square at Nether Wallop, where it may flood gardens. Lighter rain (up to 10mm) is forecast on Friday (06/02/2026). River levels will remain higher than normal, and flood risk will continue into the weekend. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible . Over a month's rain (69mm) has fallen in the last week. 
We expect the Idsworth Lavant to be flowing. Pumps which may prevent water from entering property may be required. Surface water may flood property during heavier rain events. Further rain (up to 20mm) is forecast on Thursday (05/02/2026). Lighter rain is forecast from Friday (06/02/2026) to Sunday (08/02/2026). If heavy rain affects the area, then groundwater levels will rise into next week. From this weekend, road flooding, including Chalton Road in Finchdean, could become deep in all villages. Cellar flooding could occur in Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 11 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 01/02/2026 due to a wet January 2026. 
In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level at Kings Somborne has risen by 14cm. Flooding could affect cellars in a small number of properties along Winchester Road, in central King's Somborne and in Little Somborne from Sunday 01/02/2026. However, the groundwater level may peak before these impacts occur. Small amounts of rain are forecast from today (30/01/2026) to Monday (02/02/2026). If heavy rain affects Kings Somborne and Little Somborne, groundwater levels will continue rising well into next week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hermitage Stream
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. Today is forecast to be dry. Tomorrow (05/02/2026) up to 15mm of rainfall is forecast. If realised the river will rise again. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: Titchfield on the River Meon
items.message: River levels remain high and flooding is continuing to affect Titchfield Hill with very high water levels at Titchfield Mill, Bridge Cottage and at the Tanneries Industrial Estate. Further rainfall (25mm) is forecast tomorrow. If as much rain falls as forecast, river levels will rise and there could be further flooding. While groundwater and river levels are currently so high, any intense rainfall events are now likely to cause surface water flooding in Titchfield High Street. Ensure any flood protection products you may have are activated. River levels will remain higher than normal, and flood risk will continue into the weekend. This message will be updated by 16:00 05/02/2026.

items.description: Sandown, Brading and Bembridge on the Eastern Yar
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding tomorrow. 
Flooding is expected on 05 February 2026 as further rainfall (25mm) is forecast tomorrow.   
Flooding is affecting Moreton Common and Golf Links roads. Fort Holiday Park and Sandown Sewage works could flood as ditches struggle to drain to the main river. Impacts are also expected at Nicholas Close, Brading. River levels will remain higher than normal, and flood risk will continue into the weekend. 
We are checking rivers for blockages and operating Bembridge sluices. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lavant
items.message:
High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 as 5-10mm of rain is forecast Thursday Morning. 
No rain is forecast Wednesday, but minor flooding will continue to affect fields, roads and gardens. River levels will rise Thursday, but not significantly higher than recent days. From 09:00 05/02/2026, minor flood impacts could affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane, the Green, and bridges across the river in East Lavant. Water could also approach gardens of properties at The Sadlers in Westhampnett. More rain is forecast Thursday evening through Friday, which could increase flood risk again. River levels will remain high most of February. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and operating structures in Westhampnett for the Flood Alleviation Scheme. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk Avoid roads that flood (Sheepwash Lane). Report blockages to 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.
